questiontext.text:
In a fairground ride a person sits in a chair attached by a cable to a tall post. The ride spins, causing the rider and chair to travel in a horizontal circle at a constant angular velocity, $$w$$.



If the rider and chair combined have a mass, $$m$$, of 154 kg and the length of the cable, $$l$$, is 10 m, calculate the value of $$w$$ required to maintain an angle of 48 degrees with the vertical.

(Assume a value of $$g$$ of 9.8 m/s2)

$$w$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=1.21:0.0242#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s

What is the rider's angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$?

$$\alpha$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s2

With what frequency, $$f$$, is the rider rotating?

$$f$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0.19:0.0038#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} Hz

What is the rider's linear velocity, $$V$$?

$$V$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=8.99:0.1798#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s

What is the rider's linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$?

$$a_r$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=10.88:0.2176#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

What is the rider's linear tangential acceleration, $$a_t$$?

$$a_t$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

(Please give all of your answers correct to 2.d.p. and in the specified units)

(Question ID #1)

generalfeedback.text:
For the rider to travel at a constant velocity, all forces must be balanced.


The downward force to consider in this case is the weight of the rider:

$$m\cdot g=154\times 9.8=1509.2 N$$

This must be balanced by the upwards force, supplied by the tension, $$T$$, in the cable:

$$1509.2=T\cdot cos(48)$$

Therefore,

$$T=1509.2/cos(48)=2255.46N$$


Using simple trigonometry, the radius of the circle, $$r$$, that the rider rotates in can be calculated as follows:

$$r=10\times sin(48)=7.43$$ m.


Next we need to consider horizontal forces.

The horizontal force supplied by the tension in the cable is equal to:

$$T\cdot sin(48)=1676.14N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=1676.14N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{1676.14}{r\cdot m}}=1.21$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.19Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=8.99$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=10.88$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from Dynamics lecture notes.

hint.text:
HINT

To answer this question simply draw a force diagram showing balanced forces in both the horizontal and and vertical planes.

The three forces at play here are the tension in the cable, gravity, and the centripetal force of the angular motion.

Concentrate on calculating $$\omega$$ first before answering any other parts of the question.

questiontext.text:
In a fairground ride a person sits in a chair attached by a cable to a tall post. The ride spins, causing the rider and chair to travel in a horizontal circle at a constant angular velocity, $$w$$.



If the rider and chair combined have a mass, $$m$$, of 186 kg and the length of the cable, $$l$$, is 10 m, calculate the value of $$w$$ required to maintain an angle of 51 degrees with the vertical.

(Assume a value of $$g$$ of 9.8 m/s2)

$$w$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=1.25:0.025#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s

What is the rider's angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$?

$$\alpha$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s2

With what frequency, $$f$$, is the rider rotating?

$$f$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0.2:0.004#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} Hz

What is the rider's linear velocity, $$V$$?

$$V$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=9.7:0.194#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s

What is the rider's linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$?

$$a_r$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=12.1:0.242#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

What is the rider's linear tangential acceleration, $$a_t$$?

$$a_t$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

(Please give all of your answers correct to 2.d.p. and in the specified units)

(Question ID #2)

generalfeedback.text:
For the rider to travel at a constant velocity, all forces must be balanced.


The downward force to consider in this case is the weight of the rider:

$$m\cdot g=186\times 9.8=1822.8 N$$

This must be balanced by the upwards force, supplied by the tension, $$T$$, in the cable:

$$1822.8=T\cdot cos(51)$$

Therefore,

$$T=1822.8/cos(51)=2896.46N$$


Using simple trigonometry, the radius of the circle, $$r$$, that the rider rotates in can be calculated as follows:

$$r=10\times sin(51)=7.77$$ m.


Next we need to consider horizontal forces.

The horizontal force supplied by the tension in the cable is equal to:

$$T\cdot sin(51)=2250.97N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=2250.97N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2250.97}{r\cdot m}}=1.25$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.2Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=9.7$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=12.1$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from Dynamics lecture notes.

To answer this question simply draw a force diagram showing balanced forces in both the horizontal and and vertical planes.

The three forces at play here are the tension in the cable, gravity, and the centripetal force of the angular motion.

Concentrate on calculating $$\omega$$ first before answering any other parts of the question.

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=2369.08N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2369.08}{r\cdot m}}=1.7$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.27Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=10.4$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=17.68$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

questiontext.text:

If the rider and chair combined have a mass, $$m$$, of 190 kg and the length of the cable, $$l$$, is 9 m, calculate the value of $$w$$ required to maintain an angle of 47 degrees with the vertical.

(Assume a value of $$g$$ of 9.8 m/s2)

$$w$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=1.26:0.0252#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s

What is the rider's angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$?

$$\alpha$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s2

With what frequency, $$f$$, is the rider rotating?

$$f$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0.2:0.004#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} Hz

$$V$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=8.32:0.1664#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s

generalfeedback.text:
For the rider to travel at a constant velocity, all forces must be balanced.


The downward force to consider in this case is the weight of the rider:

$$m\cdot g=190\times 9.8=1862 N$$

This must be balanced by the upwards force, supplied by the tension, $$T$$, in the cable:

$$1862=T\cdot cos(47)$$

Therefore,

$$T=1862/cos(47)=2730.21N$$


Using simple trigonometry, the radius of the circle, $$r$$, that the rider rotates in can be calculated as follows:

$$r=9\times sin(47)=6.58$$ m.


Next we need to consider horizontal forces.

The horizontal force supplied by the tension in the cable is equal to:

$$T\cdot sin(47)=1996.75N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=1996.75N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{1996.75}{r\cdot m}}=1.26$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.2Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=8.32$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=10.51$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

$$a_t$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

(Please give all of your answers correct to 2.d.p. and in the specified units)

generalfeedback.text:
For the rider to travel at a constant velocity, all forces must be balanced.


The downward force to consider in this case is the weight of the rider:

$$m\cdot g=136\times 9.8=1332.8 N$$

This must be balanced by the upwards force, supplied by the tension, $$T$$, in the cable:

$$1332.8=T\cdot cos(61)$$

Therefore,

$$T=1332.8/cos(61)=2749.12N$$


Using simple trigonometry, the radius of the circle, $$r$$, that the rider rotates in can be calculated as follows:

$$r=6\times sin(61)=5.25$$ m.


Next we need to consider horizontal forces.

The horizontal force supplied by the tension in the cable is equal to:

$$T\cdot sin(61)=2404.43N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=2404.43N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2404.43}{r\cdot m}}=1.84$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.29Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=9.63$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=17.68$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In a fairground ride a person sits in a chair attached by a cable to a tall post. The ride spins, causing the rider and chair to travel in a horizontal circle at a constant angular velocity, $$w$$.



If the rider and chair combined have a mass, $$m$$, of 163 kg and the length of the cable, $$l$$, is 10 m, calculate the value of $$w$$ required to maintain an angle of 65 degrees with the vertical.

(Assume a value of $$g$$ of 9.8 m/s2)

$$w$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=1.52:0.0304#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s

What is the rider's angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$?

$$\alpha$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s2

With what frequency, $$f$$, is the rider rotating?

$$f$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0.24:0.0048#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} Hz

What is the rider's linear velocity, $$V$$?

$$V$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=13.8:0.276#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s

What is the rider's linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$?

$$a_r$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=21.02:0.4204#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

What is the rider's linear tangential acceleration, $$a_t$$?

$$a_t$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

(Please give all of your answers correct to 2.d.p. and in the specified units)

(Question ID #24)

generalfeedback.text:
For the rider to travel at a constant velocity, all forces must be balanced.


The downward force to consider in this case is the weight of the rider:

$$m\cdot g=163\times 9.8=1597.4 N$$

This must be balanced by the upwards force, supplied by the tension, $$T$$, in the cable:

$$1597.4=T\cdot cos(65)$$

Therefore,

$$T=1597.4/cos(65)=3779.77N$$


Using simple trigonometry, the radius of the circle, $$r$$, that the rider rotates in can be calculated as follows:

$$r=10\times sin(65)=9.06$$ m.


Next we need to consider horizontal forces.

The horizontal force supplied by the tension in the cable is equal to:

$$T\cdot sin(65)=3425.64N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=3425.64N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{3425.64}{r\cdot m}}=1.52$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.24Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=13.8$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=21.02$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from Dynamics lecture notes.

hint.text:
HINT

To answer this question simply draw a force diagram showing balanced forces in both the horizontal and and vertical planes.

The three forces at play here are the tension in the cable, gravity, and the centripetal force of the angular motion.

Concentrate on calculating $$\omega$$ first before answering any other parts of the question.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=2226.77N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2226.77}{r\cdot m}}=1.25$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.2Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=9.7$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=12.1$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

questiontext.text:
In a fairground ride a person sits in a chair attached by a cable to a tall post. The ride spins, causing the rider and chair to travel in a horizontal circle at a constant angular velocity, $$w$$.



If the rider and chair combined have a mass, $$m$$, of 176 kg and the length of the cable, $$l$$, is 8 m, calculate the value of $$w$$ required to maintain an angle of 57 degrees with the vertical.

(Assume a value of $$g$$ of 9.8 m/s2)

$$w$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=1.5:0.03#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s

What is the rider's angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$?

$$\alpha$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s2

With what frequency, $$f$$, is the rider rotating?

$$f$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0.24:0.0048#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} Hz

What is the rider's linear velocity, $$V$$?

$$V$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=10.06:0.2012#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s

What is the rider's linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$?

$$a_r$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=15.09:0.3018#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

What is the rider's linear tangential acceleration, $$a_t$$?

$$a_t$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

(Please give all of your answers correct to 2.d.p. and in the specified units)

(Question ID #32)

generalfeedback.text:
For the rider to travel at a constant velocity, all forces must be balanced.


The downward force to consider in this case is the weight of the rider:

$$m\cdot g=176\times 9.8=1724.8 N$$

This must be balanced by the upwards force, supplied by the tension, $$T$$, in the cable:

$$1724.8=T\cdot cos(57)$$

Therefore,

$$T=1724.8/cos(57)=3166.87N$$


Using simple trigonometry, the radius of the circle, $$r$$, that the rider rotates in can be calculated as follows:

$$r=8\times sin(57)=6.71$$ m.


Next we need to consider horizontal forces.

The horizontal force supplied by the tension in the cable is equal to:

$$T\cdot sin(57)=2655.96N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=2655.96N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2655.96}{r\cdot m}}=1.5$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.24Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=10.06$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=15.09$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

$$a_r$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=10.51:0.2102#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

What is the rider's linear tangential acceleration, $$a_t$$?

$$a_t$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

(Please give all of your answers correct to 2.d.p. and in the specified units)

generalfeedback.text:
For the rider to travel at a constant velocity, all forces must be balanced.


The downward force to consider in this case is the weight of the rider:

$$m\cdot g=151\times 9.8=1479.8 N$$

This must be balanced by the upwards force, supplied by the tension, $$T$$, in the cable:

$$1479.8=T\cdot cos(47)$$

Therefore,

$$T=1479.8/cos(47)=2169.8N$$


Using simple trigonometry, the radius of the circle, $$r$$, that the rider rotates in can be calculated as follows:

$$r=10\times sin(47)=7.31$$ m.


Next we need to consider horizontal forces.

The horizontal force supplied by the tension in the cable is equal to:

$$T\cdot sin(47)=1586.89N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=1586.89N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{1586.89}{r\cdot m}}=1.2$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.19Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=8.77$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=10.51$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from Dynamics lecture notes.

The three forces at play here are the tension in the cable, gravity, and the centripetal force of the angular motion.

Concentrate on calculating $$\omega$$ first before answering any other parts of the question.

The three forces at play here are the tension in the cable, gravity, and the centripetal force of the angular motion.

Concentrate on calculating $$\omega$$ first before answering any other parts of the question.

questiontext.text:
In a fairground ride a person sits in a chair attached by a cable to a tall post. The ride spins, causing the rider and chair to travel in a horizontal circle at a constant angular velocity, $$w$$.



If the rider and chair combined have a mass, $$m$$, of 184 kg and the length of the cable, $$l$$, is 9 m, calculate the value of $$w$$ required to maintain an angle of 61 degrees with the vertical.

(Assume a value of $$g$$ of 9.8 m/s2)

$$w$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=1.5:0.03#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s

What is the rider's angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$?

$$\alpha$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s2

With what frequency, $$f$$, is the rider rotating?

$$f$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0.24:0.0048#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} Hz

What is the rider's linear velocity, $$V$$?

$$V$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=11.8:0.236#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s

What is the rider's linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$?

$$a_r$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=17.68:0.3536#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

What is the rider's linear tangential acceleration, $$a_t$$?

$$a_t$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

(Please give all of your answers correct to 2.d.p. and in the specified units)

(Question ID #47)

generalfeedback.text:
For the rider to travel at a constant velocity, all forces must be balanced.


The downward force to consider in this case is the weight of the rider:

$$m\cdot g=184\times 9.8=1803.2 N$$

This must be balanced by the upwards force, supplied by the tension, $$T$$, in the cable:

$$1803.2=T\cdot cos(61)$$

Therefore,

$$T=1803.2/cos(61)=3719.4N$$


Using simple trigonometry, the radius of the circle, $$r$$, that the rider rotates in can be calculated as follows:

$$r=9\times sin(61)=7.87$$ m.


Next we need to consider horizontal forces.

The horizontal force supplied by the tension in the cable is equal to:

$$T\cdot sin(61)=3253.06N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=3253.06N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{3253.06}{r\cdot m}}=1.5$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.24Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=11.8$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=17.68$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from Dynamics lecture notes.

The three forces at play here are the tension in the cable, gravity, and the centripetal force of the angular motion.

Concentrate on calculating $$\omega$$ first before answering any other parts of the question.

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=1136.8N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{1136.8}{r\cdot m}}=1.24$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.2Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=7.9$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=9.8$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If the rider and chair combined have a mass, $$m$$, of 112 kg and the length of the cable, $$l$$, is 10 m, calculate the value of $$w$$ required to maintain an angle of 75 degrees with the vertical.

$$V$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=18.8:0.376#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s

The downward force to consider in this case is the weight of the rider:

Using simple trigonometry, the radius of the circle, $$r$$, that the rider rotates in can be calculated as follows:

$$r=10\times sin(75)=9.66$$ m.


Next we need to consider horizontal forces.

The horizontal force supplied by the tension in the cable is equal to:

$$T\cdot sin(75)=4096.3N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=4096.3N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{4096.3}{r\cdot m}}=1.95$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.31Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=18.8$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=36.57$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

What is the rider's linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$?

$$a_r$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=36.57:0.7314#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

What is the rider's linear tangential acceleration, $$a_t$$?

$$a_t$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

(Please give all of your answers correct to 2.d.p. and in the specified units)

(Question ID #62)

generalfeedback.text:
For the rider to travel at a constant velocity, all forces must be balanced.


The downward force to consider in this case is the weight of the rider:

$$m\cdot g=168\times 9.8=1646.4 N$$

This must be balanced by the upwards force, supplied by the tension, $$T$$, in the cable:

$$1646.4=T\cdot cos(75)$$

Therefore,

$$T=1646.4/cos(75)=6361.2N$$


Using simple trigonometry, the radius of the circle, $$r$$, that the rider rotates in can be calculated as follows:

$$r=7\times sin(75)=6.76$$ m.


Next we need to consider horizontal forces.

The horizontal force supplied by the tension in the cable is equal to:

$$T\cdot sin(75)=6144.45N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=6144.45N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{6144.45}{r\cdot m}}=2.33$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.37Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=15.73$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=36.57$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from Dynamics lecture notes.

Concentrate on calculating $$\omega$$ first before answering any other parts of the question.

To answer this question simply draw a force diagram showing balanced forces in both the horizontal and and vertical planes.

The three forces at play here are the tension in the cable, gravity, and the centripetal force of the angular motion.

Concentrate on calculating $$\omega$$ first before answering any other parts of the question.

questiontext.text:
In a fairground ride a person sits in a chair attached by a cable to a tall post. The ride spins, causing the rider and chair to travel in a horizontal circle at a constant angular velocity, $$w$$.



If the rider and chair combined have a mass, $$m$$, of 126 kg and the length of the cable, $$l$$, is 8 m, calculate the value of $$w$$ required to maintain an angle of 52 degrees with the vertical.

(Assume a value of $$g$$ of 9.8 m/s2)

$$w$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=1.41:0.0282#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s

What is the rider's angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$?

$$\alpha$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s2

With what frequency, $$f$$, is the rider rotating?

$$f$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0.22:0.0044#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} Hz

What is the rider's linear velocity, $$V$$?

$$V$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=8.89:0.1778#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s

What is the rider's linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$?

$$a_r$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=12.54:0.2508#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

What is the rider's linear tangential acceleration, $$a_t$$?

$$a_t$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

(Please give all of your answers correct to 2.d.p. and in the specified units)

(Question ID #70)

generalfeedback.text:
For the rider to travel at a constant velocity, all forces must be balanced.


The downward force to consider in this case is the weight of the rider:

$$m\cdot g=126\times 9.8=1234.8 N$$

This must be balanced by the upwards force, supplied by the tension, $$T$$, in the cable:

$$1234.8=T\cdot cos(52)$$

Therefore,

$$T=1234.8/cos(52)=2005.65N$$


Using simple trigonometry, the radius of the circle, $$r$$, that the rider rotates in can be calculated as follows:

$$r=8\times sin(52)=6.3$$ m.


Next we need to consider horizontal forces.

The horizontal force supplied by the tension in the cable is equal to:

$$T\cdot sin(52)=1580.47N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=1580.47N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{1580.47}{r\cdot m}}=1.41$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.22Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=8.89$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=12.54$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from Dynamics lecture notes.

The three forces at play here are the tension in the cable, gravity, and the centripetal force of the angular motion.

Concentrate on calculating $$\omega$$ first before answering any other parts of the question.

$$T\cdot sin(70)=3015.63N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=3015.63N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{3015.63}{r\cdot m}}=2.02$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.32Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=13.31$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=26.93$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

questiontext.text:

If the rider and chair combined have a mass, $$m$$, of 124 kg and the length of the cable, $$l$$, is 10 m, calculate the value of $$w$$ required to maintain an angle of 67 degrees with the vertical.

(Assume a value of $$g$$ of 9.8 m/s2)

$$w$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=1.58:0.0316#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s

What is the rider's angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$?

$$\alpha$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s2

With what frequency, $$f$$, is the rider rotating?

$$f$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0.25:0.005#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} Hz

What is the rider's linear velocity, $$V$$?

$$V$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=14.58:0.2916#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s

What is the rider's linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$?

$$a_r$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=23.09:0.4618#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

What is the rider's linear tangential acceleration, $$a_t$$?

$$a_t$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

The downward force to consider in this case is the weight of the rider:

Using simple trigonometry, the radius of the circle, $$r$$, that the rider rotates in can be calculated as follows:

$$r=10\times sin(67)=9.21$$ m.


Next we need to consider horizontal forces.

The horizontal force supplied by the tension in the cable is equal to:

$$T\cdot sin(67)=2862.83N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=2862.83N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2862.83}{r\cdot m}}=1.58$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.25Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=14.58$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=23.09$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

$$V$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=11.29:0.2258#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s

What is the rider's linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$?

$$a_r$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=23.09:0.4618#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

What is the rider's linear tangential acceleration, $$a_t$$?

$$a_t$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

(Please give all of your answers correct to 2.d.p. and in the specified units)

(Question ID #85)

generalfeedback.text:
For the rider to travel at a constant velocity, all forces must be balanced.


The downward force to consider in this case is the weight of the rider:

$$m\cdot g=135\times 9.8=1323 N$$

This must be balanced by the upwards force, supplied by the tension, $$T$$, in the cable:

$$1323=T\cdot cos(67)$$

Therefore,

$$T=1323/cos(67)=3385.96N$$


Using simple trigonometry, the radius of the circle, $$r$$, that the rider rotates in can be calculated as follows:

$$r=6\times sin(67)=5.52$$ m.


Next we need to consider horizontal forces.

The horizontal force supplied by the tension in the cable is equal to:

$$T\cdot sin(67)=3116.79N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=3116.79N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{3116.79}{r\cdot m}}=2.04$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.33Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=11.29$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=23.09$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from Dynamics lecture notes.

The three forces at play here are the tension in the cable, gravity, and the centripetal force of the angular motion.

Concentrate on calculating $$\omega$$ first before answering any other parts of the question.

questiontext.text:
In a fairground ride a person sits in a chair attached by a cable to a tall post. The ride spins, causing the rider and chair to travel in a horizontal circle at a constant angular velocity, $$w$$.



If the rider and chair combined have a mass, $$m$$, of 122 kg and the length of the cable, $$l$$, is 7 m, calculate the value of $$w$$ required to maintain an angle of 66 degrees with the vertical.

(Assume a value of $$g$$ of 9.8 m/s2)

$$w$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=1.86:0.0372#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s

What is the rider's angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$?

$$\alpha$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} rad/s2

With what frequency, $$f$$, is the rider rotating?

$$f$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0.3:0.006#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} Hz

What is the rider's linear velocity, $$V$$?

$$V$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=11.86:0.2372#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s

What is the rider's linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$?

$$a_r$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=22.01:0.4402#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

What is the rider's linear tangential acceleration, $$a_t$$?

$$a_t$$= {1:NUMERICAL:=0:0#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s2

(Please give all of your answers correct to 2.d.p. and in the specified units)

(Question ID #93)

generalfeedback.text:
For the rider to travel at a constant velocity, all forces must be balanced.


The downward force to consider in this case is the weight of the rider:

$$m\cdot g=122\times 9.8=1195.6 N$$

This must be balanced by the upwards force, supplied by the tension, $$T$$, in the cable:

$$1195.6=T\cdot cos(66)$$

Therefore,

$$T=1195.6/cos(66)=2939.49N$$


Using simple trigonometry, the radius of the circle, $$r$$, that the rider rotates in can be calculated as follows:

$$r=7\times sin(66)=6.39$$ m.


Next we need to consider horizontal forces.

The horizontal force supplied by the tension in the cable is equal to:

$$T\cdot sin(66)=2685.36N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=2685.36N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{2685.36}{r\cdot m}}=1.86$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.3Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=11.86$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=22.01$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

$$T=1117.2/cos(59)=2169.16N$$


Using simple trigonometry, the radius of the circle, $$r$$, that the rider rotates in can be calculated as follows:

$$r=10\times sin(59)=8.57$$ m.


Next we need to consider horizontal forces.

The horizontal force supplied by the tension in the cable is equal to:

$$T\cdot sin(59)=1859.33N$$

This force must be balanced by the centripetal force of the angular motion of the rider.

This can be calculated by applying Newton's second law of motion ($$F=m\cdot a$$), where $$a$$ is the linear radial acceleration, $$a_r$$, given by $$\omega^2\cdot r$$.

Therefore,

$$m\cdot \omega^2\cdot r=1859.33N$$.

Therefore,

$$\omega=\sqrt{\frac{1859.33}{r\cdot m}}=1.38$$ rad/s.


The remainder of the question is relatively straightforward once the value of $$\omega$$ has been calculated.

The angular acceleration, $$\alpha$$ is zero rad/s2, as there is no change in the angular velocity.

The relationship $$\omega=2\cdot \pi\cdot f$$ can be used to calculate $$f=0.22Hz$$

The relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$ can be used to calculate $$V=11.82$$ m/s.

The relationship $$a_r=\omega^2\cdot r$$ can be used to calculate $$a_r=16.31$$ m/s2.

As the rider has a constant linear velocity (or alternatively a constant angular velocity), the linear tangential acceleration $$a_t$$ is zero m/s.

hint.text:
HINT

To answer this question simply draw a force diagram showing balanced forces in both the horizontal and and vertical planes.

The three forces at play here are the tension in the cable, gravity, and the centripetal force of the angular motion.

Concentrate on calculating $$\omega$$ first before answering any other parts of the question.
